awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in Computer Vision
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is a continuation of a Research Experience for Undergraduates site in Computer  Vision which has operated successfully at the University of Central Florida for the past twenty-one years. Approximately two hundred and ten undergraduate students from forty-three institutions  all over the country have participated in this program over the years. The research focus area is Computer Vision. The current proposal is to have 10 participants per year, for three years. Each year, students will participate in a 12-week duration full-time Summer program. From lessons learned in  prior years, the proposed model includes round-the-clock mentoring by a team that includes a professor,  and a post-doctoral fellow or a graduate student; a streamlined short course that lets participants  start their research projects sooner; and daily meetings with mentors to plan activities throughout the  day. Participants take the short course, match themselves to a project topic that they most desire, and  spend sufficient time in focused research. They then can opt for follow-through over the year by working  with the professors to write a technical report on their project, to prepare for the GREs and to apply  to graduate programs. In past years, a substantial fraction of our REU participants have been able to  prepare a paper for submission to a refereed conference, have the paper accepted and then attend the  conference to present the paper. The site is Co-funded by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.  

Intellectual Merit:
Development of new algorithms for solving scientific problems in learning  scene models, super-resolution enhancement, object detection, tracking, activity and event recognition.  Both theory and practice is involved with an interest in mathematical modeling and analysis of  difficult vision problems and developing algorithms, while at the same time building real systems for  demonstrating those solutions in real life situations.  

 Broader Impacts:
The project will contribute to preparing a work force of young scientists in order to  maintain America's previously-held strategic position of command in Science and Engineering. Participants  will be trained in Computer Vision, in particular they will learn fundamentals of image science  and vision, which plays an important role in security/surveillance, gaming, entertainment, healthcare,  defense, and manufacturing. Through this project we will able to provide opportunities to a diverse  group of undergraduates, many from predominantly undergraduate institutions, to spend a summer with  a highly successful research group. This model for REU will be disseminated among other Schools.

por.por_cntn:
Background and Explanation:

Twenty-nine U.S. undergraduates  (citizens and permanent residents) in computer science and engineering have been trained in the procedures of research during a twelve-week summer immersion at UCF.Focusing on the area that enables computers to gain visual perception capabilities, the students were first provided training in the concepts and procedures that lead to exploration in this field.Then the students were provided introductions to many on-going projects led by advanced researchers and were encouraged to commit to one project. In subsequent weeks, the student under the guidance of the advanced researchers worked to put into practice their recently learned skills with the aim of discovering or inventing previously unknown technology. All students completed a project report, and four students completed reports that won placement in highly competitive, reviewed, scientific publication venues.

In addition to pursuing their goals of strengthening their abilities to conduct research, all students were given guidance on ethical issues, were taken on field trips to interact with Corporate researchers, and were provided with substantial information on how to continue their pathway of maturing as a researcher by enrolling in competitive training programs (graduate study) to become advanced researchers.About half of the students have continued  on this path, while the other half have proceeded to take their research skills to industrial settings.

 

Intellectual Merits:

All students were involved in investigating and pursuing the creation of new knowledge. A new capability for understanding patterns of motion by statistical modelling was created. A new capability to train systems that learn from one example was created. A new capability for using business directories to guide business scene recognition was invented. Several improvements to the ability to correctly show where in an image a human's parts appear were developed.

 

Broader Impacts:

The training model employed is now mature, it has achieved a high degree of success in providing undergraduates with good preparation to become advanced researchers. The model is also capable of successfully training a diverse population of students, including students who are attending college for the first time in their family's history.



Last Modified: 06/28/2013
Modified by: Mubarak Shah
